Hi. Does anyone know if anyone has already studied free inversions of arrows into adjoint isomorphisms?

More precisely, it's known that the walking isomorphism of (∞,n)(\infty, n)(∞,n)-categories is not contractible, but it's variant with more additional data, the walking adjoint isomorphism, is supposed to always be contractible (https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00567). On the other side, it seems that it's always the case one can individually upgrade isomorphisms to adjoint ones.

Now, one can consider a variant of localisation for some class of 111-cells WWW in a (∞,n)(\infty, n)(∞,n)-category CCC, C[W−adj]C [W^{-adj}]C[W−adj], such that every arrow in WWW becomes, instead, an adjoint isomorphism.

Has anyone ever studied before this variant of localisation? I'm particularly interested in conditions guaranteeing C[W−adj]≅C[W−1]C [W^{-adj}] \cong C [W^{-1}]C[W−adj]≅C[W−1] (maybe that's almost never the case, though).

The standard meaning of C[W−1]C[W^{-1}]C[W−1] will always be equivalent to your C[W−adj]C[W^{-\mathrm{adj}}]C[W−adj], because it refers to forcing 1-cells to have the property of being an isomorphism rather than the structure of a non-adjoint isomorphism.

Mike Shulman said:

The standard meaning of C[W−1]C[W^{-1}]C[W−1] will always be equivalent to your C[W−adj]C[W^{-\mathrm{adj}}]C[W−adj], because it refers to forcing 1-cells to have the property of being an isomorphism rather than the structure of a non-adjoint isomorphism.

I'm confused. I feel like I'm overseeing something extremely trivial. Let's restrict everything to (2,1)(2, 1)(2,1)-cats. Shouldn't Δ1[Δ−1]\Delta^1[\Delta^{-1}]Δ1[Δ−1] and Δ1[Δ−adj]\Delta^1[\Delta^{-adj}]Δ1[Δ−adj] be respectively the walking isomorphism and the walking adjoint isomorphism? If so, the latter is always supposed to be equivalent to the terminal category, while the former cannot satisfy so according to Prop. 1.3.2 of the aforementioned paper...

No, as I said, Δ1[(Δ1)−1]\Delta^1[(\Delta^1)^{-1}]Δ1[(Δ1)−1] means Δ1\Delta^1Δ1 with the morphism freely forced to have the property of being an isomorphism, which is equivalent to having the structure of an adjoint isomorphism.

Mike Shulman said:

No, as I said, Δ1[(Δ1)−1]\Delta^1[(\Delta^1)^{-1}]Δ1[(Δ1)−1] means Δ1\Delta^1Δ1 with the morphism freely forced to have the property of being an isomorphism, which is equivalent to having the structure of an adjoint isomorphism.

Hmm... Let me see if I've got it. So the point is that every pair of 111-cells fff and ggg together with 222-cells fg≅1fg \cong 1fg≅1 and gf≅1gf \cong 1gf≅1 can be modified to another one by changing the 222-cells so that the triangle identities are true. And that doesn't contradict the non-contractibility of the walking iso because liftings from an isomorphism datum to an adjoint isomorphism datum are not unique (if they were unique, the walking iso would be equivalent to the walking adjoint iso). Did I interpret your reply properly?

But, then, it seems that the usual localisation formula, where one takes pushouts along coproducts of the inclusions into walking isos Δ1→Δiso1\Delta^{1} \rightarrow \Delta^{1}_{\text{iso}}Δ1→Δiso1​ can be instead computed using Δ1→Δadj-iso1≅1\Delta^{1} \rightarrow \Delta^{1}_{\text{adj-iso}} \cong 1Δ1→Δadj-iso1​≅1... I'm skeptic that's always the case. Maybe I'm overseeing something again?

Fernando Yamauti said:

But, then, it seems that the usual localisation formula, where one takes pushouts along coproducts of the inclusions into walking isos Δ1→Δiso1\Delta^{1} \rightarrow \Delta^{1}_{\text{iso}}Δ1→Δiso1​

I don't know where you saw that, but that is not the correct localization formula when working with nnn-categories for n>1n>1n>1; you do have to use the walking adjoint isomorphism. My point was that this is what is generally meant by the notation C[W−1]C[W^{-1}]C[W−1].
In other words, the version where you force things to become non-adjoint isomorphisms is the one that's a "variant" of localization, which I doubt anyone has studied very much.

Mike Shulman said:

I don't know where you saw that, but that is not the correct localization formula when working with nnn-categories for n>1n>1n>1; you do have to use the walking adjoint isomorphism. My point was that this is what is generally meant by the notation C[W−1]C[W^{-1}]C[W−1].

Wait. I recall seeing written somewhere (I'm still trying to find it) that the simplicial localisation of a 111-cat could be computed using homotopy pushouts (in the Joyal model structure) along (the nerve of) inclusions of Δ1\Delta^1Δ1's into walking 111-isomorphisms (everything is a 111-cat here). That can't be correct then?
Ah! The nerve of the "walking isomorphism" 1-category is the walking adjoint (∞,1)(\infty,1)(∞,1)-isomorphism! This is kind of magic, but it's true.

Mike Shulman said:

Ah! The nerve of the "walking isomorphism" 1-category is the walking adjoint (∞,1)(\infty,1)(∞,1)-isomorphism! This is kind of magic, but it's true.

So that's the source of all my confusion until now! Btw, is that a general pattern? That is: for whatever geometric nerve from (m,m)(m, m)(m,m)-cats and any nnn, should it always be the case that applying the nerve and truncating to the homotopy (n,n)(n, n)(n,n)-cat sends the "walking iso" mmm-cat to the "walking adjoint iso" nnn-cat? That seems to work for the Duskin nerve...

I would say that this operation should send the walking adjoint isomorphism mmm-category to the walking adjoint isomorphism nnn-category. It's just that for 1-categories, there is no difference between isomorphisms and adjoint isomorphisms.

Mike Shulman said:

I would say that this operation should send the walking adjoint isomorphism mmm-category to the walking adjoint isomorphism nnn-category. It's just that for 1-categories, there is no difference between isomorphisms and adjoint isomorphisms.

Ah! Ok. Thanks. Duh! Of course, if the triangle identities are not true, then there's no 333-cell in the Duskin nerve filling the boundary of the tetrahedron with two degenerated faces and one face for the (co)unity. So nothing weird happens as expected and all the usual nerves are good models for inclusions into higher dimensions (which should always be conservative, so no non-contractible object can become contractible).

Let me just add something that summarise why Δ1[(Δ1)−1]≅Δadj-iso1\Delta^1 [(\Delta^{1})^{-1}] \cong \Delta^1_{\text{adj-iso}}Δ1[(Δ1)−1]≅Δadj-iso1​. @Mike Shulman , let me know if I'm not spilling any bullshit.

The point is: if a ⁣:Δ1→Ca \colon \Delta^1 \rightarrow Ca:Δ1→C defines an arrow that happens to be invertible, then the space of choices of liftings of aaa along the canonical inclusion Δ1→Δiso1\Delta^1 \rightarrow \Delta^1_{\text{iso}}Δ1→Δiso1​ is not contractible, while there is exactly one unique lifting of aaa (up to contractible space of choices) Δadj-iso1→C\Delta^1_{\text{adj-iso}} \rightarrow CΔadj-iso1​→C along the inclusion Δ1→Δadj-iso1\Delta^1 \rightarrow \Delta^1_{\text{adj-iso}}Δ1→Δadj-iso1​. And all that is simply equivalent to the contractibility of Δadj-iso1\Delta^1_{\text{adj-iso}}Δadj-iso1​!

That clarifies a fundamental misunderstanding I had regarding localisations of higher stuff.
